segments.text: Since she was little, she had many words that she kept silent, words written in her mind and heart quietly, whole chapters without any chronological order, sometimes from the end and sometimes from the beginning, sometimes even a story written from the middle.
They would pile up inside her, as if she already knew back then that she would have to remember everything to cherish those magical days of her childhood.
That beginning, because when everything started, she was only two years old.
And when it ended, it was three months after she turned 18.
There is a big difference between the eyes of a two-year-old and those of an 18-year-old who is still essentially young.
Only to an outsider did the young girl seem fully grown, carrying the burden of memories, longings, and the responsibilities of adulthood.
Somewhere two years earlier, or perhaps even before that, her magical childhood ended and the journey began.
It is difficult to pinpoint exactly when it happened.
Maybe it was a process throughout that year, perhaps intermittently even earlier,
as there was a long pause of five years from the first time Lucy fell ill until her illness was discovered again.
That time she was only 11 and didn't fully understand what was happening, but something changed nonetheless.
Lucy became quieter, a bit cautious, and it also affected the atmosphere at home.
It wasn't a regular house.
First of all, it was pink.
That was its name and its address.
without a street name or number, just the pink house.
All the letters knew how to reach it, as did the people, since there was a hotel and a restaurant, and at night, a bar.
Only for them was it their home, with a large garden and red shutters, standing out among all the other white houses.
and there was a mom and dad and a dog and one very happy little girl with a big smile on her face.
For the first 10 years, this house was a kind of wonderland with colorful and fascinating guests who sometimes stayed for long periods.

like the oil rigors who came from Texas and looked like characters from Western movies, like Jerry Wolf, who was her private pirate because of the earring he had in his ear, and the soldiers from the commando unit who would arrive early in the morning and sleep on the grass until Lucy would cook them the game meat they left at her kitchen door, and there were mom and dad's friends from the Tel Aviv Bohemia,
famous theater actors, writers, singers and poets, who found a refuge in this house and sometimes even created there.
And Shoshana Damari, of course, who was a close friend of Lucy from the days of Leela Lowe and the Broome Theater, where Lucy worked as a costume designer.
She would call her sweet Yemenite and bring her gifts from her travels around the world.
And there were, of course, the locals for whom this house was also a pilgrimage site to eat and spend time.
The regulars were like uncles to her, and in between there were always changes.

And when she was 10, Josef went down for a year to the Dead Sea to manage the youth hostel in Sodom, and she would occasionally visit him there, a little girl hitchhiking with anyone going south or bringing her back home full of experiences and new landscapes.
When she turned 11, Yosef suddenly returned home and only much later did she understand that it happened because Lucy fell ill for the first time.
Afterward, there was a period when they moved briefly to Mike Morett because Yosef was supposed to manage a new holiday village being built for some Spanish millionaire.
For her, it was quite a magical time.
She rode alone along the Alexander River, found treasures along the bank, and their rented house stood right on the beach, accessible with 10 steps.
Only Lucy was miserable, feeling bad most of the time, heavily medicated and rarely leaving the house.
In the mornings, she would sometimes ask her to pick purple grapes from the vines outside.
She taught her how to remove grape by grape from the cluster, place them in a fine sieve over a bowl, then press them with a glass until there was enough juice to fill the glass.
Lucy would drink it eagerly, explaining that it was full of vitamins and iron, and that it would strengthen her.
This whole episode lasted only a few months and when.
The school year began.
Lucy and Yosef arranged with Carmela and Xavi, the neighbors of the pink house, for her to move in with them, so she could continue her studies in the same class and with the same friends.
It was already clear that they would return home within a month or two.
and that the whole dream of the Spanish-style holiday village would not materialize soon, if at all.
All that remained then were two sample bungalows, at the same time.
The one who rented the pink house from them didn't really know what he was doing, and they quickly wanted it back before he destroyed their gem.
She enjoyed sharing a room with other children.
Even before, they had always been close to each other's homes and spent a lot of time together, visiting each other.
Xavi always adored her, and she did him, and Carmella had wonderful records of music with magical songs that she would sing with loudly while doing house chores.
They welcomed her warmly without making a fuss, and she enjoyed suddenly being part of a family with other children.

Freckles, her ginger-cocker spaniel who came after Shakes, her Irish setter, also ginger, was already gone, having moved earlier to Dina, the neighbor's daughter, where they pampered and fed him non-stop until he became so fat that they started calling him Specky, meaning pork chop.
In short, everyone found a place, and even though Lucy and Yosef were slightly distant from her, it wasn't a big sadness, maybe just a sliver of longing before bed.
No more.
Two months later, they returned to the pink house, and everything fell back into place.
Lucy returned to life in her corner, reorganizing her pearl as she loved, polishing and arranging everything.
Once again, there were ironed tablecloths with vases of flowers on every table, the garden was properly watered.
Sweet peas were sown along the house walls, and violas and elisms were planted along the entrance path, and the garden lifted its head as if to say thank you.

So five more full and good years passed until the illness returned, striking mercilessly from all sides, adding types and metastases, knocking Lucy off her feet, taking her away from her home to long weeks in an unfamiliar room in the hospital.
Private and good as it may have been, around her were only nurses and doctors and trials with medications and relentless pains from which there was nowhere to escape.
They would take shifts between them, traveling between Ashkelon and the hospital in Tel Aviv.
One time him, one time her, so she wouldn't feel lonely, and neither would they.
In the winter of 1965, Lucy's condition worsened.
It was clear she had only a few weeks left.
Two weeks, maybe less.
She wanted to come home, insisted on it.
Tired of all the treatments and pains, she missed home and wanted to end her life in her bed, in her room, with her loved ones near in their natural surroundings.
There was immense relief on the decision Lucy made, almost joy.
She was very tired from the non-stop bus trips for long months between Ashkelon and Tel Aviv, one time her, one time Yosef.
Lucy didn't always greet her warmly.
She wanted her to remember her as beautiful as she was.
And when she understood what it was about, she solemnly promised to remember her just like that.
And indeed, this is how she sees her even now.
How could it be otherwise?
Whose mom is such a lady with gray eyes and gray hair adorned with a white streak at the front?
Joseph made all the necessary arrangements.
He arranged shifts for nurses day and night, and Dr. Horowitz would visit her twice daily on his way to work and back home.
He would stroke her hand, sometimes adding more morphine to ease her pain and telling her in English, Lucy, don't fight it.
Let it help you.
That's how she wanted it, to be at home as both Yosef and the little one entered and exited her room countless times a day.
It surrounded her with peace.
Sometimes when she suddenly opened her eyes, she would see the little ones sitting at the edge of her bed.
Gently holding her hand and looking at her with compassion and concern, as if she were checking if she was still with her.
In moments when her strength held, she would try to bring a faint.
Smile to her lips and whisper, I'm still here.
In the first week, while she still had hours of full consciousness, she sent her to bring the shoebox full of pictures.
She sat on the edge of her bed, pulling out one picture after another from the box and waiting for explanations.
Suddenly, she drew out two photos clipped together, separated them, and read the back.
To Dad, with love and longing from your son, Amnon, age three.
Lucy sighed heavily, mustering all the strength she didn't have, and began to explain slowly, pausing from time to time, sipping tiny amounts of water through a straw.
Even swallowing them was now hard for her.
She knew she had to tell her because Yosef wouldn't.
This is Dad's son from his first marriage.
Actually, his only marriage.
He and I were never married.
He lived with his first wife until our son turned one.
Then he left, perhaps ran away to the brigade, and never returned to her.
He would visit him occasionally.
But she didn't make it easy for him during those visits, until one day he decided no more.
And from the moment it ended, we didn't talk about it any more.
For years, his wife refused to grant him a divorce until she wished to remarry and agreed.
When it was finally possible for them to divorce, I thought there was no point.
Maybe I preferred to keep the name of Abraham, who was my husband for only two weeks when he was murdered by Arab rioters at Cafe Ganha Aviv in Tel Aviv, which he owned.

She showed her a photo of them, sitting on wicker chairs at the cafe, and explained that the man seated to her right was Mayor Tiamim, who was also killed in that attack, and he was the father of stage actor Oded Tiamim.
As she held the picture, tears welled up in her eyes.
Soon I'll meet him again.
She said, with a shadow of a smile, he probably won't recognize me.
Look at me.
All my life I've struggled to lose two or three kilos, and now I have the body of a child slimmer than you.
And then her eyes closed, and she drifted into sleep.
Shocked and shaken, Leora remained seated at the edge of Lucy's bed, trying to digest the hidden secrets that surfaced, and came with a confession of a few minutes.
Suddenly, she also had a brother.
And her father was actually her mother's ex, but not her husband.
And her mother was not only the ex-wife of Shmuel, her sister's father.
She was actually the widow of a man named Abraham.
And how is it that even though she never married her father, everyone calls her Mrs. Friedman?
She looked at her, recognizing how once again, almost in the middle of the sentence, she slipped into a sort of sleep or morphine-induced unconsciousness.
That was all the doctor could do to ease her last days.
It didn't always help.
Sometimes, from that deep sleep, she would groan with choked pain.
In moments when she fell asleep, Leora would leave her room to the hallway, call for the nurse sitting on the lounge chair for a break, and step outside into the air.
Taking a deep breath, she waited for the clean air to fill her lungs without that undefined smell that filled her room.
One morning, a few minutes before six, the night nurse knocked on Leora's door to check if she was awake, so she could replace her until the morning nurse arrived.
Leora quickly washed her face and stood by Lucy's bed, releasing the nurse.
She sat beside her, tenderly stroking her hand, very carefully not to cause pain, watching her sleep her unconscious sleep, and slowly began to notice how her face became completely peaceful.
as if an invisible hand was ironing out and erasing every wrinkle and sign of suffering or pain.
She frowned, beginning to comprehend that something was wrong, took her hand, still warm into hers, but deep down, she knew she was no longer there.

so she remained seated for a long moment, her limp hand in hers, unable to let go, repeatedly looking at her calm, beautiful face, brushing away a gray lock of hair from her forehead, and only then did she slowly rise and leave the room.
She passed through the hallway and saw Yosef standing and shaving in front of.
The open bathroom door
She caught his eye in the mirror and met him with a look full of pain.
For a moment, he didn't understand her gaze's meaning, and then he heard her quietly say, Daddy, Mom stopped suffering.
And that was it.
The end of the beginning.
